lg.l: I am about to tell you for your pity,
I am a Roman born, of good descent;
My father noble (Of the Candiani)
Howe'er decayed in fortune, ere he died;
Which drew on my misfortune: for, being betrothed
Unto a wealthy heir, here, of this city,
Who so journed then in Rome, his covetous father
Ravished his faith from me, to give't another;
And called him hastily from Rome to Venice.
I followed him, in hope to cross the match.
And so regain him; towards which already,
I have done something.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: What in this habit, as a courtesan?

lg.l: Not without good advice: for, by this means
I draw the eyes of all the youthful gentry,
Not without hope to gain a sight of him.
My price and port keep back inferior persons.
Nor lose I honour by it: for the strictness
Of our Italian censure gives a virgin,
That held familiarity with any man,
By way of marriage treaty, and then forsaken,
Lost in repute; she is no honest woman
Until that man do vindicate her honour.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: But should he find you here, what were his censure?

lg.l: Here he should find what his disloyalty
Had wrought me to; and should restore me firm
On my first basis, or exchange a life
For mine ere we would part.
I'll trust thee now. Thou art a noble wench,
Thou hadst kissed death by this else. Now I'll trust thee.
If he were lost by marriage of another,
I would remove with such a testimony
Of my reserved honour (In despite
Of this my outward carriage, for my ends;
Maugre the stern construction of my country)
That strangers should receive me; and some one
More noble than himself —

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: 'Tis done, and I am he that does it.

lg.l: I cannot sir, but kindly take your offer:
But, if my first love fail me, there is one,
A noble german, that commenced his suit
To me this day.
I am he too lady — look well upon me
that in this shift, reducing of my beard,
With this supply of money came to try you,
I find you noble, and above it, honest.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: This is the german that Fabritio apes.

lg.l: Gentlemen forbear;
Indeed it is not civil in you to pry beyond
Your hospitable usage, pray forbear.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: 'Tis timely chidden wench, we will obey thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Besides the bridegroom, and the bride expect you.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: O ha they done we come, we come.

lg.l: This jealous trial now of yours ( howe'er
You have expressed strong arguments of love)
Has not augmented you in my affection.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: O say not so sweet lady, I'll redeem it.

lg.l: I cannot yet believe you are the man,
You are so changed from what you seemed today,
Must the mind alter with the outward habit?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Here he is man, he says.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I say he is without, and craves to see you.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: How can this be? or who can I believe?

lg.l: Good sir depart and make room for yourself
Your proper self to enter the Dutch prince.
I tell thee I am he, and here already,
I am Swatzenberg.
Yes in your tother beard sir.
Hans Snortanfart, are you not? well I can but warn you,
If you will needs stand to the taking off
A man's good name from him before his face,
Then take what follows, I will fetch him in
Mistress, you were best be out of sight a while:
your presence with this stranger may whet up his fury
To cut all our throats else.
For sir I'll tell you, if you had but seen
How he worried a Spaniard today, you would
Have been able at your return to make
As many of your countrymen, as thrive
By serving of the states to laugh i'faith.
I tell thee I am he; 'twas I that chased
The Spaniard hence.
I tell you yet again
You were best be gone before the he indeed
Come in to chase you after him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: See his impatience pulls him in already.

div.stage: Enter Fabritio in the Germanes habit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Where is this lady? Dos her beauty fly me?

lg.l: She is at hand, but first here is a stranger,
A most strange stranger that says he is you sir.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Was oder waer bistu? Bistu ein deutscher? Sag mihr in was ort Du gelebst haste?

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Ich denke du bist ein heuchler; bistu aber ein deutscher so anwort mihr in deutscher sprach.

lg.l: Good sir speak in the proper language of
The nation we are in, though it come brokenly
From you that this good fellow here may understand us.
Thou son of impudence, and imposture, speak;
What is thy end in this?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Think what thine own must be, thou son of slander.

lg.l: Precious counterfeit!
But I am weaponless, and must fetch strength
Of officers to right me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What dos your shame remove you sir?

lg.l: I care not honest fellow, where's thy mistress?
Good angels guard me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I ask thee for thy mistress, the Novella.

lg.l: Thou powerful man in magic, I will tell thee.
Thou'st raised an apparition, that has damned thee
Blacker, than thy black art; nay hell itself.
The heavenly spirit, that inspired this form,
(When the unworthy world enjoyed her being,
Which thou hast conjured into this lewd habit)
Has, at this instant won the powers above
To sink thee and thy sorcerers.
What may you mean? Here is no sorcery,
This woman's flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I would not dare to try to be the Duke.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: You may depart, pray hinder not the house.

lg.l: Hadst thou but seen, as I have, one like her,
And noted the divinity in her looks
(Although in those adulterate incitements
She seems to wear) she would have struck thy soul
With fervent adoration, not base lust.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I know not what to say to 'Him.

lg.l: See who rings. Exit Paulo.
What divine creature, sir, was that you mentioned?
I dare to name her to thee, though thou be
Her incensed ghost, to work me to despair,
It was Victoria.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: This sounds most strangely! Have you been at Rome sir?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: 'Twas there I saw and loved her.

lg.l: Answer me pray sir, why could not this fall
in your discourse today, when I related
My life and fortune to you? why do you start?
I am no shadow; but suspect you rather,
To be not as you seem, the noble german
That vowed me love, dos that too startle you?
See sir, to prove I am no airy spirit,
I'll trust your hand (If you be mortal substance)
With so much flesh and blood as may resolve you.
I find 'tis she, and having found her thus
She's lost for ever, and myself no less,
That was the cause of this her desperate fortune.
What's that you say? what ail you sir? how is't?
And what moves thy distraction? Borgio, speak.
Horror and shame invades us, all the house
Is round beset with officers. The magistrates,
Are entering now, for what, or whom they search
I cannot guess, unless this be some murderer
Slipped in, to draw our lives in question.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Deal plainly sir, what are you? he's stupefied!

lg.l: The spanyard's with 'em too that took th'affront
By the supposed Dutchman here today;
And he that feigned himself to be that Dutchman
Desires their aid against this unknown person.

div.stage: Enter Pantaloni, Pedro, Guadagni, Swatz. Prospero, Checquino, Zaffi, pedlar-woman.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: This is the house you say.

lg.l: Here's no such creature, here sir, if she be
Your daughter, this woman directed hither,
She is no harlot, but an honest bride;
Lawfully wed and bedded; as may appear
by the strong testimony of divers friends:
Call them all down.
Unheard-of impudence! Are bawds, and whores
Fit matchmakers for magnifico's daughters?
Speak lower, or at home sir, you know not
What we are: hark you sir — your last night's trial
Did not enough inform you.
We shall know more anon;
I'th' mean time what are you?

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: We shall know more of that anon too.

lg.l: This is the stranger, that affronted me;
'Gainst whom I crave your justice.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: You shall know more anon too.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: You also shall know more anon.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: You are well met gentlewoman — I gave you lost.

div.stage: Enter Paulo, Francisco, Piso, Horat, Flavia, Astutta, Jacconetta.

lg.l: What will you whimper now? will not marriage
Make you bold, that makes so many impudent?
She was not lost sir; nor in danger of losing,
She was but mislaid a little, as your writing was today.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Well said my chattering magpie. I will side thee.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Audacious strumpet that seduces my daughter.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: You are mistaken, she did but wait upon her.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Right sir, and did but duty I'll be sworn.

sp.speaker: Pedlar
sp.p: Nor I, I will be sworn.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Not, in consenting to the stealth?

lg.l: It was my duty sir for the reward,
we all would live you know.
I hope I am discharged: for look you sir,
I brought you where you find your daughter safe.

sp.speaker: Pedlar
sp.p: No whit the worse for wearing, as they say.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Go thrust her out of doors.

sp.speaker: Pedlar
sp.p: At my own liberty I hope.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: How thou wilt to be rid of thee.

sp.speaker: Pedlar
sp.p: May you see your children's, children's, children's, children.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: And thou misledst my son, I ask him of thee.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: You shall know more of that anon sir.

lg.l: Outbraved and scorned by strumpets, bawds, and bravoes!
Call in the officers.
And call the common hangman if you please,
And end all among yourselves, if your grave wisdoms,
And lawyers, here, can find one guilty person
We'll all submit our necks to you.

div.stage: Horatia and Francisco, etc. talk aside with Fabritio and Victoria.

lg.l: I will speak but truth.
And you, opposing it, shall wrong the dignity
You bear i'th' city, to your utter shames.
This gentleman and your daughter were contracted,
Yourself a willing witness; your son likewise
Unto a noble virgin (Sir of whom
You shall know more anon)
It pleased diviner providence to take
From either's chosen mate their earthly fortunes;
Yet each had person, blood, and virtue left
Above the value of a prince's dowry.
Would you so kick at heaven then, in despite
Of its great ordinance, as to force your children,
to forfeit both their faiths, thereby to lose
The never-failing hope of future blessings,
To pull withal a curse on your own heads,
That could no less than ruin your estates,
And render you most wretched in your dotage,
Passed help or hope how to relieve yourselves:
Your consciences still groaning underneath
The lashes that your children's bastard issue
Should lay upon you? more, you may consider —
We do consider sir, this place and people
No fit receipt for warrantable business.
This was no bawdy talk sir, nor have I
Heard worse from any mouth in this free place
Till your arrival here.
You see the worst of us, I should be loath
Any unwarrantable act should pass among us.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Thou lookest like one indeed of upright conscience!

lg.l: And for the marriage sir, it is as lawful
As if yourself had given her in st. marks.
I'll fetch the priest t'avouch it.

div.stage: Paulo joins in conference with Victoria and Fabritio.

lg.l: But I'll be so revenged
Upon this instrument, this unknown trull here —

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Our ears and eyes, Fabritio, witness for her.

lg.l: You have told me wonders,
Yet with such faith as I shall ever wish
Locked in this heavenly cabinet I take all.
You may Fabritio, for as I prize life;
Honour above that; and above both thy friendship,
My soul is not assured of firmer truth,
let thy Dutch habit drink off jealousy,
And take her to thee.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: And I made happy passed my height of hopes.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Good, you shall see how I shall cool those kisses.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: May I say boldly you are man and wife?

lg.l: We are most faithfully till death;
I'll fetch a priest shall straight pronounce ye so.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: You say that is a Dutchman sir, that wronged you.

sp.speaker: Pedlar
sp.p: Right, worthy signior, that's the man I challenge.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: You say you are the man confronted don here.

lg.l: Yes, and will still maintained, for violence
He offered to that noble virtuous lady.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Good! virtuous lady! Let me join your friendships.

sp.speaker: Pedlar
sp.p: That is the man I challenge.

lg.l: The same man I. He has not left the house
Since my abuse; I fear to her much wrong:
For he is some disguised knave on my life.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Now you are in the right.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: He could not wear those clothes and speak no Dutch else.

lg.l: Still i' the right; I'll show you what he is,
And out of him, what she is, whom you call
So virtuous and so noble! and you sir,
That mentioned the hangman, come all and see
The commendable port this lady bears.
It seems, sir, you affect this gentlewoman.
Would that were true i'faith. The rogue your man
Said he would fetch a priest —

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No verier rogue than myself sir.

lg.l: Thou art a mad fellow for a priest indeed;
But such a priest, such a marriage,
Put 'em together.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I do pronounce them lawful man and wife.

lg.l: The bridegroom thanks you, but you mistress Bride
For the fine trick you put on me last night,
Look now upon your husband,
Who would you speak with fellow?
With signior Rastrofico here, the hangman,
I come to call him to state-business sir.
Can this be he? (You said he was a counterfeit)
I saw him ride the wooden-horse, last day
With less than half this beard, unbeard him sirrah.
I'll bear you out. So rest you gentlemen
With your so virtuous lady, and her husband.
Sir I must crave your pardon, this is he,
My first love that I told you of.
I thank you sir for all the harm you did me
In your revenge — and hark you, be at peace,
And I'll be silent for your last night's work.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Forbear me, I am off again.

lg.l: Good sir,
Stop not the blessing you were about to give us.
I am off again. The pander was the priest,
The match is no match, you no more my children,
But knave and strumpet.
I'll not be so cozened.
This is no priest; and all that's passed unlawful

div.stage: Paulo casts off his perruk and beard.

lg.l: Then cast your eyes on me, who dare maintain
My priesthood lawful; it being derived
From th'holy order of st. Augustine?
Let me not surfeit with excess of joy?
My brother Paulo!
Thy brother and thy father, virtuous sister.
Be ever subject of my dearest care;
And pardon me, who (Jealous of thine honour
Inflamed by the same heart, of the same blood:
For we are all the relics of our parents)
Watched nearly, and pursued thy scape from Rome.
For which I had good warrant, gentlemen
See there my dispensation with th' allowance
Of all the holy brotherhood of my covent.
My ends were fair, though in this uncouth way
Though (Heaven I beg thy pardon) as my care
Was to preserve her life and more her honour;
Fearing her violent and abused spirit,
Might have made wrack of either, or of both,
I once had secret purpose to have taken
Her life, in case she had forsook her honour;
And with her cut off Candiany's line,
Which now branched here, may touch the world's end
With fair succession! Be you blessed for ever.
And now, grave sirs, let me entreat your likings,
And cheerful reconcilement to your children:
That so you may your children's, children see,
Crowned by the prayers of your prosperity.
And I, but for one scruple
Clear me this point, how had you saved your honour
If the old youth, last night (Who shall be nameless)
Had but miss ▪ spent his time upon your Moor here?
'Tis easily done sir, see my loved Fabritio
The eunuch Moor you gave me.
My boy Jacomo, turned chambermaid!
Has thy mistress used thee well?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: She means for your dear sake sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I see, sweet heart, you have an honest family.

lg.l: Here you see all, and all that came i'th' house;
(Since it was made mine) in this convention,
I dare them not; but give them freest leave
To speak the worst they found in the Novella.
All's well accorded then. We all are friends,
And may priests travail never to worse ends.
'Cause 'tis the custom, by the poet, sirs,
I'm sent to crave a plaudit, and the spurs
That prick him on to't, is, his promised pay
May chance to fail, if you dislike the play,
But don't if you be wise; for he has vowed
To write far worse if this be not allowed.
